questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bainbridge reflex

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Option C. Cushing Reflex: Cushing reflex is a protective reflex that helps save the brain tissues from ischemic effects during the periods of reduced cerebral blood flow. It is also called Cushing reaction, response or phenomenon.

 

Option D. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that increases heart rate in response to increased venous return, enhancing cardiac output to match the increased blood flow into the heart.

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periaqueductal gray

 

The analgesia system consists of three major components:

 

(1) The periaqueductal gray and periventricular areas of the mesencephalon and upper pons surround the aqueduct of Sylvius and portions of the third and fourth ventricles. Neurons from these areas send signals to  

 

(2) the raphe magnus nucleus, a thin midline nucleus located in the lower pons and upper medulla, and the nucleus reticularis paragigantocellularis, located laterally in the medulla. From these nuclei, second-order signals are transmitted down the dorsolateral columns in the spinal cord to

 

(3) a pain inhibitory complex located in the dorsal horns of the spinal cord. At this point, the analgesia signals can block the pain before it is relayed to the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticospinal tract: Incorrect. This tract is involved in motor control and voluntary movements, not pain relief.

 

Option C. Medial lemniscus: Incorrect. This pathway carries sensory information related to touch, vibration, and proprioception, not pain relief.

 

Option D. Medial longitudinal fasciculus: Incorrect. This bundle of nerve fibers coordinates eye movements and helps maintain balance, not pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a critical component of the analgesia system, responsible for relieving pain by sending inhibitory signals to block pain transmission in the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroxine

 

Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.

 

The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process. Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Epinephrine: Incorrect. Epinephrine is a catecholamine that acts on cell surface receptors (adrenergic receptors) and does not cross the plasma membrane to exert its effects.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Incorrect. Glucagon is a peptide hormone that binds to receptors on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin is a peptide hormone that binds to its receptor on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Educational objective

 

Thyroxine (T4) crosses the plasma membrane and binds to intracellular receptors to exert its effects, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanisation in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20-25 Hz

 

Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 25Hz.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as à 1/contraction period.

 

As per the graph -

  • ﻿﻿Paper speed - 1000mm/sec.
  • ﻿﻿y-axis represents force of muscle contraction millivolts
  • x-axis represents duration of contraction in milliseconds with a scale of 10mm
  • ﻿﻿The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • ﻿﻿Area under the graph is the muscle contraction.

 

Contraction period the duration from latent period to maximum force of contraction

So, in the given graph,

Contraction period is approximately 4 scales i.e., 40 mm.

As the speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec, contraction period = 40mm = (40/1000) = 40 msec = 0.04sec

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective

 

Tetanisation

 

As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called tetanization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha actinin

 

The image shows a sarcomere and the arrow marks the Z line which is constituted by Alpha actinin.

 

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

 

 

  • Each muscle fiber contains several hundred to several thousand myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril is composed of about 1500 adjacent myosin filaments and 3000 actin filaments.
  • The thick filaments are myosin, and the thin filaments are actin
  • The myosin and actin filaments partially interdigitate and thus cause the myofibrils to have alternate light and dark bands.
  • The light bands contain only actin filaments and are called I bands because they are isotropic to polarized light.
  • The dark bands contain myosin filaments, as well as the ends of the actin filaments where they overlap the myosin, and are called A bands because they are anisotropic to polarized light.
  • Small projections from the sides of the myosin filaments are cross-bridges. The interaction between these cross-bridges and the actin filaments that causes contraction.
  • The ends of the actin filaments are attached to a so-called Z disc. From this disc, these filaments extend in both directions to interdigitate with the myosin filaments.
  • The Z disc is composed of filamentous proteins different from the actin and myosin filaments, passes
  • crosswise across the myofibril and also crosswise from myofibril to myofibril, attaching the myofibrils to one another all the way across the muscle fiber. Therefore, the entire muscle fiber has light and dark bands, as do the individual myofibrils giving the skeletal and cardiac muscle their striated appearance.
  • The portion of the myofibril (or of the whole muscle fibre) that lies between two successive Z discs is called a sarcomere.

 

Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second-best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: A thin filament protein that interacts with myosin for muscle contraction but is not specific to the Z line.

 

Option C. Titin: A large elastic protein that spans from the Z line to the M line, providing elasticity and stabilizing the sarcomere's structure. Although titin is associated with the Z line, alpha actinin is the primary constituent.

 

Option D. Tropomyosin: A protein that lies along the actin filament and regulates muscle contraction by controlling access to the myosin-binding sites on actin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Z line in a sarcomere is primarily constituted by alpha actinin, which plays a critical role in anchoring actin filaments and maintaining the structural integrity of the muscle fiber.

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventricular filling

 

The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling.

 

  • Atrial Heart Sound (Fourth Heart Sound) – Occurs when the atria contract, and presumably, it is caused by the inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

 

Other heart sounds:

 

  • First heart sound – contraction of the ventricles first causes sudden backflow of blood against the A-V valves (the tricuspid and mitral valves) causing them to close producing the first heart sound.
  • The second heart sound results from sudden closure of the semilunar valves at the end of systole.
  • Third Heart Sound – occasionally a weak, rumbling third heart sound is heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. Most probably it is due to oscillation of blood back and forth between the walls of the ventricles initiated by inrushing blood from the atria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by the atrial contraction and the subsequent inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with respiratory volume of 500ml. The intrapleural pressure measured -4 before inspiration and -8 at the end of inspiration. The pulmonary compliance of the patient is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A) 125 ml/cm H20

 

The compliance of a system is defined as the change in volume that occurs per unit change in the pressure of the system.

 

Compliance is, therefore, a measurement of the elastic resistance of a system.

 

Pulmonary compliance (C) total compliance of both lungs, measuring the extent to which the lungs will expand (change in volume of lungs) for each unit increase in the trans-pulmonary pressure (when enough time is allowed for the system to reach equilibrium).

 

Compliance = Change in lung volume / Change in pressure

 

In the given case, change in lung volume is 500 and change in transpulmonary pressure is 4

Compliance = 500/4 = 125 ml/cm H20

 

Educational Objective

 

Pulmonary compliance measures the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. It is a crucial indicator of the lung's ability to expand and is affected in various pulmonary diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DHEA-S

 

DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS.

 

Adrenal hormones

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa – Aldosterone
  2. Zona fasciculata – glucocorticoids cortisol, corticosterone, as well as small amounts of adrenal androgens and estrogens
  3. The zona reticularis – adrenal androgens dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA. and androstenedione, as well as small amounts of estrogens and some glucocorticoids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: Incorrect. Progesterone is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option B. DHEA: Incorrect. DHEA is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen is produced by both the ovaries and the adrenal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DHEA-S (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is exclusively secreted by the adrenal glands and not by the ovaries because the ovaries lack the enzyme necessary to produce DHEA-S.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenal Insufficiency

 

Darrow Yannet diagrams are graphs that tell you the osmolarity and volume changes of body fluids. X axis represents volume. Y axis represents solute concentration.

 

 

 

Addison's disease is adrenal insufficiency. Aldosterone makes you retain sodium so in the absence of aldosterone, you will lose sodium.) so osmolarity of ECF will decrease. ECF volume will decrease as fluid will move from ECF to ICF, thus ICF volume will increase.

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-Bötzinger complex

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex is a group of neurons located in the ventrolateral medulla of the brainstem, which is responsible for generating the basic rhythm of breathing. It is considered the primary respiratory rhythm generator, as it sets the pace for breathing and coordinates the activity of other respiratory neurons in the brainstem.

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex receives input from a variety of sources, including chemoreceptors, mechanoreceptors, and cortical areas, which help to adjust the respiratory rhythm based on changing physiological demands. It also sends signals to other respiratory centers in the brainstem, such as the dorsal respiratory group, which modulate the depth and rate of breathing.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumotaxic centre: Incorrect. It modifies the respiratory rate and pattern but does not generate the basic rhythm.

 

Option B. Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla: Incorrect. It regulates respiratory muscles and processes sensory information related to breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

 

Option D. Apneustic centre: Incorrect. It influences the pattern of breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

 

Educational objective

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex, located in the ventrolateral medulla, is the primary respiratory rhythm generator. It sets the basic pace of breathing by generating rhythmic bursts of activity that drive the respiratory muscles, coordinating with other respiratory centers to modulate the breathing pattern based on the body's needs.

 

The pneumotaxic center and apneustic center are other respiratory centers located in the pons and medulla, respectively, which help to adjust the respiratory pattern by modifying the duration and intensity of inhalation and exhalation. The dorsal respiratory group is a cluster of neurons in the medulla that is involved in the regulation of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor

 

When a person changes posture from supine to standing, the immediate effect is a decrease in mean arterial pressure (MAP) due to gravity causing blood to pool in the lower extremities. This results in decreased venous return and cardiac output and decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase: Incorrect. The vagal (parasympathetic) output decreases when standing to allow an increase in heart rate and cardiac output.

 

Option C. Mesenteric vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Although mesenteric vasoconstriction occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is not the immediate response; the initial response is the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Option D. Increase cardiac contractility: Incorrect. While increased cardiac contractility occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is a subsequent response following the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate response when a person changes posture from supine to standing is a decrease in baroreceptor firing due to a reduction in mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: Where do afferent fibers from baroreceptors primarily project for blood pressure control? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

 

Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).

 

The afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control primarily project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS). The NTS is located in the medulla oblongata, which is part of the brainstem. It serves as the primary site for integrating and processing information related to blood pressure regulation.

 

The baroreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the walls of certain blood vessels, particularly in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. These receptors detect changes in blood pressure and relay this information via afferent (sensory) nerve fibers. The afferent fibers from the baroreceptors transmit signals to the NTS, where they are integrated and contribute to the regulation of blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleus ambiguous: Incorrect. This nucleus is involved in controlling the muscles of the pharynx, larynx, and soft palate.

 

Option B. Rostral-ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in the regulation of sympathetic outflow but does not receive direct input from baroreceptor afferents.

 

Option D. Caudal ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in regulating blood pressure but is not the primary projection site for baroreceptor afferents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Afferent fibers from baroreceptors project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) in the medulla oblongata, where they integrate and process information related to blood pressure regulation.

questions.text: "a" wave on JVP is for: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

 

 

The "a" wave on the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing represents atrial contraction. This wave occurs when the right atrium contracts, pushing blood into the right ventricle. It is the first positive deflection in the JVP waveform and is a key component in assessing right atrial pressure and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial filling: Incorrect. Atrial filling is represented by the v wave, which occurs as the atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole.

 

Option C. Ventricular relaxation: Incorrect. Ventricular relaxation corresponds to the x descent and y descent in the JVP tracing.

 

Option D. Ventricular filling: Incorrect. Ventricular filling is associated with the y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Na, K

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

During the early portion of the action potential, the ratio of sodium to potassium conductance increases more than 1000-fold. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

 

Then the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels to open, so that the ratio of conductance shifts far in favor of high potassium conductance but low sodium conductance. This allows very rapid loss of potassium ions to the exterior but virtually zero flow of sodium ions to the interior.

Consequently, the action potential quickly returns to its baseline level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, sodium conductance increases first (Channel A), followed by an increase in potassium conductance (Channel B), causing depolarization and subsequent repolarization of the neuron.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ascending thick loop of Henle

 

The thick ascending limb has a sodium hydrogen counter-transport mechanism in its luminal

cell membrane that mediates sodium reabsorption and hydrogen secretion in this segment.

 

The thick segment of the ascending loop of Henle is virtually impermeable to water.
 

Therefore, most of the water delivered to this segment remains in the tubule, despite reabsorption of large amounts of solute. The tubular fluid in the ascending limb becomes very dilute as it flows toward the distal tubule. Hence it is called the diluting segment of the kidney.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The PCT is primarily involved in reabsorbing water, sodium, and other solutes, but it is not considered the diluting segment.

 

Option B. Collecting duct: Incorrect. The collecting duct is involved in the reabsorption of water and solutes and is influenced by hormones like ADH, but it is not the primary diluting segment.

 

Option D. Descending loop of Henle: Incorrect. The descending loop of Henle is permeable to water but not to solutes, making it responsible for concentrating the tubular fluid, not diluting it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle is the diluting segment of the kidney due to its impermeability to water and active reabsorption of solutes

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

Normally in the PCT, Glucose & Amino Acid maximally approx. 100% reabsorbed; Bicarbonate approx.-80-85% and about 60-70 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. Hence, the concentration of chloride relatively increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid: The concentration of amino acids decreases significantly as they are almost entirely reabsorbed in the PCT.

 

Option B. Glucose: Glucose concentration also decreases drastically due to nearly complete reabsorption in the PCT.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: A large percentage of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT, leading to a decrease in its concentration in the filtrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other substances, which are more extensively reabsorbed. This includes glucose and amino acids, which are almost completely reabsorbed, and bicarbonate, which is substantially reabsorbed.

questions.text: On performing a Histamine test on an individual with brachial plexus trunk injury, you can expect? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare

 

In patient with brachial plexus trunk injury, there is anesthesia over the skin in that region. Histamine test in this patient will result in capillary dilatation and wheal without surrounding flare.

 

Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin which includes a red reaction, flare and wheal.

 

  • Red reaction is because of capillary dilatation and is independent of innervation.
  • Flare reaction is due to dilatation of arterioles caused by the axon reflex.
  • Axon reflex or antidromic reflex is the process by which the impulses are conducted in a direction opposite to the normal direction. Normally, the impulses produced by a cutaneous pain receptor pass through sensory nerve fiber towards the nerve cell body in posterior nerve root ganglion. Some of these impulses pass through the other branches of the same fiber in the opposite direction and reach the blood vessels supplied by these branches. Impulses now dilate the blood vessels. This is called the antidromic or axon reflex. Thus, flare is absent in anesthetized skin.
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to increased capillary permeability

 

The triple response can be seen after total sympathectomy

 

The incomplete triple response over the anesthetic skin is characteristic of postganglionic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a brachial plexus trunk injury, the histamine test will result in central capillary dilatation and a wheal without the surrounding flare due to the disruption of the axon reflex.

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ functions as a crucial sensory receptor that provides important feedback to the central nervous system, contributing to muscle control, injury prevention, and maintaining appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

 

The Golgi tendon organ is an encapsulated sensory receptor through which muscle tendon fibers pass. About 10 to 15 muscle fibers are usually connected to each Golgi tendon organ, and the organ is stimulated when this small bundle of muscle fibers is “tensed” by contracting or stretching the muscle.

 

The major difference in excitation of the Golgi tendon organ versus the muscle spindle is that the spindle detects muscle length and changes in muscle length, whereas the tendon organ detects muscle tension as reflected by the tension in itself.

 

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex)

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Sense changes in muscle direction: Incorrect. Muscle direction changes are not detected by the Golgi tendon organ but by proprioceptors in the muscle and joints.

 

Option C. Sense changes in position of the muscle: Incorrect. This function is primarily performed by muscle spindles and joint receptors, not by the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Option D. Sense changes in length of the muscle: Incorrect. Muscle spindles are responsible for detecting changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length, not the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Golgi tendon organ is responsible for sensing changes in muscle tension, providing crucial feedback to the central nervous system to prevent muscle damage and maintain appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

Ans. D) Orange curve

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 500-600 ml

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 500-600 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When calculating the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient, it is essential to account for approximately 500-600 ml/day of insensible water loss due to evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

 

Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors occurs due to prolonged exposure to elevated vasopressin levels resulting in excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels, thus maintaining euvolemia and preventing excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. This is called as vasopressin escape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in urine osmolarity: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape does not result in an increase in urine osmolarity. Instead, it is characterized by the body's ability to excrete free water to prevent hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Decrease in ADH secretion: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape occurs despite high levels of ADH, not due to a decrease in ADH secretion.

 

Option D. Upregulation of aquaporin 2 production: Incorrect. The condition involves the downregulation, not upregulation, of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH): Pathogenesis and clinical findings

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stomach

 

Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

 

Most gastrointestinal contractions occur rhythmically, and this rhythm is determined mainly by the frequency of so-called “slow waves” of smooth muscle membrane potential or basal electrical rhythm.

 

Interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

They are slow, undulating changes in the resting membrane potential. Their intensity usually varies between 5 and 15 millivolts, and their frequency ranges in different parts of the human gastrointestinal tract from 3 to 12 per minute:

 

  • Body of the stomach – 3/min
  • Duodenum – 12/min
  • Terminal ileum – 8-9/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum has a higher frequency of slow waves, approximately 12 waves per minute.

 

Option B. Ileum: Incorrect. The terminal ileum has a frequency of about 8-9 waves per minute.

 

Option C. Jejunum: Incorrect. The jejunum has a frequency of approximately 10-12 waves per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach has the least frequency of slow waves among the given options, with approximately 3 waves per minute. Slow waves determine the rhythmic contractions of the gastrointestinal tract and vary in frequency throughout different regions.

questions.text: Which of the following is high-molecular weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to integrins? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibronectin

 

Fibronectin is a high-molecular weight (~500-~600 kDa) glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins called integrins.

 

Integrins are cell surface receptors that play a crucial role in connecting cells to their extracellular environment, including other cells and the extracellular matrix (ECM). Integrins can connect with several types of molecules and proteins, including:

 

  1. Extracellular Matrix (ECM) Proteins: Integrins can bind to various components of the ECM, such as fibronectin, laminin, collagen, and vitronectin. These interactions allow cells to anchor to the ECM and provide structural support.
  2. Cell Adhesion Molecules: Integrins can connect with other cell adhesion molecules on neighbouring cells, promoting cell-cell interactions and the formation of multicellular structures. Examples of cell adhesion molecules include cadherins, selectins, and immunoglobulin superfamily proteins.
  3. Signalling Proteins: Integrins can also associate with intracellular signalling proteins, such as focal adhesion kinases (FAK), Src family kinases, and various adapter proteins. These interactions transmit signals from the ECM to the cell's interior, influencing cellular processes like cell growth, migration, and differentiation.
  4. Blood Clotting Factors: In platelets, integrins can bind to fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor, contributing to platelet aggregation and blood clot formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cadherin: Involved in calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion.

 

Option B. Vitronectin: Also a part of the extracellular matrix but known for its role in serum spreading factor and in the promotion of cell adhesion and spreading.

 

Option D. Selectin: Plays a role in cell adhesion during the immune response, particularly in the binding of white blood cells to the endothelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibronectin is a key component of the extracellular matrix that interacts with cell surface integrins to mediate various cellular processes including adhesion, migration, and tissue repair.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, Repolarization, and hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?(INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

 

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

 

During the onset of depolarization, voltage gated sodium channels open and there is slow influx of Na+. When depolarization reaches 7 to 10 mV, the voltage gated Na+ channels start opening at a faster rate. It is called Na+ channel activation. When the firing level is reached, the influx of Na+ is very great and it leads to overshoot.

 

But the Na+ transport is short lived. It is because of rapid inactivation of Na+ channels. Thus, the Na+ channels open and close quickly. At the same time, the K+ channels start opening. This leads to efflux of K+ out of the cell, causing repolarization.

 

Unlike the Na+ channels, the K+ channels remain open for longer duration. These channels remain opened for few more milliseconds after completion of repolarization. It causes efflux of a greater number of K+ producing more negativity inside. It is the cause for hyperpolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option C. 1, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option D. 2, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels, and repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle action potential, depolarization occurs due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, repolarization occurs due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, and hyperpolarization is caused by the prolonged efflux of K+.

questions.text: What is the oxygen carrying capacity of 18-year-old boy with Hb of 14g/dl? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 18 mL/dL

 

The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is determined by the haemoglobin (Hb) concentration.

 

The average oxygen carrying capacity of haemoglobin is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of haemoglobin.

 

Oxygen carrying capacity formula:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = Hb (g/dL) × 1.34 mL/g

 

Substituting the given value:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 14 g/dL × 1.34 mL/g
  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 18.76 mL/dL
  • Therefore, the estimated oxygen carrying capacity for an 18-year-old boy with a haemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL is approximately 18.76 mL/dL.

 

Educational Objective


The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of hemoglobin, a crucial metric in assessing the oxygenation potential of blood in clinical settings.

questions.text: I-125 labelled albumin is used for measurement of: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasma volume

 

Albumin iodinated I-125 serum is a radiopharmaceutical diagnostic agent indicated for use in the determination of total blood and plasma volume.

 

The use of I-125 labeled albumin for the measurement of interstitial fluid volume, intracellular fluid volume or extracellular fluid volume is not common.

 

Other tracers, such as inulin or sucrose, are more commonly used for measuring extracellular or interstitial fluid volume, while radiolabeled water or radiolabeled potassium chloride can be used for measuring total body water and intracellular fluid volume.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Interstitial fluid volume: Incorrect. Interstitial fluid volume is typically measured using other tracers such as inulin or thiosulfate.

 

Option C. ICF (Intracellular Fluid): Incorrect. Intracellular fluid volume is not measured using I-125 labelled albumin. Methods like radiolabeled potassium or total body water (using deuterium or tritium) are used for ICF estimation.

 

Option D. ECF (Extracellular Fluid): Incorrect. Extracellular fluid volume is generally measured using tracers like inulin, which distribute throughout the extracellular compartment but do not enter cells.

 

Educational objective

 

I-125 labelled albumin is specifically used to measure plasma volume. It remains confined to the vascular compartment, making it an effective tracer for determining the volume of plasma within the circulatory system

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1-b . Transthyretin (TTR) or Prealbumin is a tetrameric transport protein highly conserved through vertebrate evolution and synthesized in the liver, choroid plexus, and retinal pigment epithelium. TTR transports the thyroid hormone thyroxine and the retinol-binding protein (RBP) bound to retinol (vitamin A).

 

 2-c. Transcobalamins are carrier proteins which bind cobalamin (B12). Transcobalamin I (TCN1), also known as haptocorrin, R-factor, and R-protein, is a glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the mouth. It primarily serves to protect cobalamin (Vitamin B12) from acid degradation in the stomach by producing a Haptocorrin-Vitamin B12 complex. Once the complex has traveled to the more neutral duodenum, pancreatic proteases degrade haptocorrin, releasing free cobalamin, which now binds to intrinsic factor for absorption by ileal enterocytes. Transcobalamin II (TCN2) binds cobalamin once it has been taken up by enterocytes of the terminal ileum and the "Intrinsic Factor-Vitamin B12" complex has been degraded. Transcobalamin II is then involved with the transport of Vitamin B12 to the tissues.

 

 3-d. Haptoglobin (abbreviated as Hp) in blood plasma, haptoglobin binds with high affinity to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, and thereby inhibits its deleterious oxidative activity. 

 

4-a. Hemopexin binds to free heme. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex will then be removed by the reticuloendothelial system (mostly the spleen).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin

2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin

3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin

4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Binding of ATP

 

Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

 

 

Energy for movement of myosin head (power stroke) is obtained by breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) into adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate (Pi). Head of myosin has a site for ATP and itself can act as the enzyme ATPase and catalyse the breakdown of ATP.

 

Even before the onset of contraction, an ATP molecule binds with myosin head.

When tropomyosin moves to expose the active sites, the head is attached to the active site. Now ATPase cleaves ATP into ADP and Pi, which remains in head itself. The energy released during this process is utilized for contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: Incorrect. The entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum helps in muscle relaxation but does not directly cause the detachment of the myosin head from actin.

 

Option C. Change in troponin C configuration: Incorrect. The change in troponin C configuration exposes the active sites on actin for myosin binding but does not cause detachment.

 

Option D. Release of ADP and Pi: Incorrect. The release of ADP and Pi occurs after the power stroke but does not cause the detachment of the myosin head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteric stone

 

Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Ureteral obstruction decreases glomerular filtration rate (GR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased renal blood flow: Correct. Increased renal blood flow increases GFR by increasing glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option B. Efferent arteriolar constriction: Correct. Efferent arteriolar constriction increases GFR by increasing glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option D. Decreased oncotic pressure: Correct. Decreased oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries increases GFR by reducing the opposing colloid osmotic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following types of amino acids are present in the trans-membranous part of the membrane receptor? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrophobic

 

Integral or transmembrane proteins are the proteins that pass through entire thickness of cell membrane from one side to the other side. These proteins are tightly bound with the cell membrane.

 

The trans membranous part of the membrane receptor consists of hydrophobic amino acids.

 

The central core of the cell membrane is hydrophobic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amphipathic: Incorrect. Amphipathic molecules contain both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions, but the transmembrane segments of proteins are primarily hydrophobic.

 

Option C. Hydrophilic: Incorrect. Hydrophilic amino acids have polar side chains that would not favorably interact with the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Hydrophobic amino acids are indeed present in the transmembranous part of the membrane receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmembrane regions of membrane receptors are composed of hydrophobic amino acids, allowing them to stably integrate into the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Examples of integral protein:

 

  1. Cell adhesion proteins
  2. Cell junction proteins
  3. Some carrier (transport) proteins
  4. Channel proteins
  5. Some hormone receptors
  6. Antigens
  7. Some enzymes.

questions.text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rods and cones

 

  • The rods and cones act as the first-order neurons They give the signals to the bipolar cells act as second order neurons in the optic pathway. They serve as an intermediate link between the photoreceptor cells and the ganglion cells (option B), which are the third-order neurons.
  • The electrical signals from the bipolar cells are further transmitted to the ganglion cells. The axons of ganglion cells form the optic nerve, which carries visual information from the retina to the visual processing centers in the brain.
  • The optic nerve fibers project to different regions of the brain, including the lateral geniculate body (option C), which is part of the thalamus and is involved in visual processing. Therefore, the correct correct answer is A.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ganglion cells: Incorrect. Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Option C. Cells in lateral geniculate body: Incorrect. These cells are involved in the later stages of visual processing and are not first-order neurons.

 

Option D. Bipolar cells: Incorrect. Bipolar cells are the second-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the optic pathway, the first-order neurons are the photoreceptor cells, specifically rods and cones, which convert light into electrical signals. These signals are then relayed through bipolar cells to ganglion cells, whose axons form the optic nerve, ultimately transmitting visual information to the brain.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary dancing movements of his right hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever. What constitutes the ganglia involved in the presenting complication? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

 

Sydenham chorea is considered to be an autoimmune disease that is triggered by a streptococci infection, subsequently resulting in a hypersensitivity humoral reaction to the infection and cross-reactivity streptococci antigens and human tissue antigens through antigen mimicry.

 

The stimulated antibodies target the basal ganglia brain cells in the host and cause a diffuse inflammatory process in the corpus striatum, mainly the caudate nucleus and putamen.

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A. Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus: Incorrect. While the caudate nucleus is involved, the globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus and putamen: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily involved in Sydenham chorea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ganglia involved in Sydenham chorea, associated with rheumatic fever, are the caudate nucleus and putamen, which are part of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolactin and growth hormone

 

The hypothalamus exerts inhibitory control on both prolactin and growth hormone:

 

  • Prolactin: Inhibition is mediated by Prolactin-Inhibiting Hormone (PIH), which is dopamine. Dopamine inhibits the secretion of prolactin by lactotropes in the anterior pituitary.
  • Growth Hormone: Inhibition is mediated by Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone (GHIH), also known as somatostatin. Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of growth hormone by somatotropes in the anterior pituitary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries

 

Explanation

 

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries.

 

Constriction of the efferent arterioles:

 

  1. Increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries raising the glomerular hydrostatic pressure
  2. Reduces renal blood flow
  3. Increase in filtration fraction and glomerular colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure)

 

Therefore, if the constriction of efferent arterioles is severe (more than about a threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the rise in colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure) exceeds the increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure caused by efferent arteriolar constriction. When this occurs, the net force for filtration actually decreases, causing a reduction in GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in GFR: Incorrect in this context as initial efferent arteriolar constriction might actually increase GFR by raising hydrostatic pressure, though severe constriction can eventually decrease it.

 

Option B. Decreases renal blood flow: Incorrect as this is a direct effect of efferent arteriolar constriction.

 

Option D. Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries: Incorrect as this is indeed a result of efferent arteriolar constriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction leads to an increase in both hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within the glomerular capillaries, which can modify renal blood flow and the dynamics of glomerular filtration. It does not decrease the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenoma is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a condition in which the parathyroid glands produce excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to a stimulus other than low blood calcium levels. This can occur in response to various conditions that cause chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or exposure to certain medications such as lithium.

 

Parathyroid adenoma, on the other hand, is a cause of primary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by excess PTH secretion due to an abnormality within the parathyroid gland itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium intake: Lithium can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism by impairing calcium sensing.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is a well-known cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its role in calcium absorption.

 

Option D. Chronic kidney disease: CKD is a major cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its effects on phosphate and vitamin D metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism, whereas secondary hyperparathyroidism is due to external stimuli such as chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or lithium intake.

Secondary active transport

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary active transport

 

  1. Glucose enters the lumen of the small intestine.
  2. Sodium ions (Na+) are present in the lumen of the intestine.
  3. Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1) on the luminal membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose absorption:
    1. SGLT1 binds to both glucose and sodium ions.
    2. Sodium ions move down their electrochemical gradient into the enterocyte, providing energy for transport.
    3. Glucose molecules are co-transported with sodium ions into the enterocyte.
  4. Glucose enters the cytoplasm of the enterocyte.
  5. Inside the enterocyte, glucose can be used for energy or transported across the basolateral membrane.
  6. Glucose Transporter 2 (GLUT2) on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose transport out of the cell:
    1. GLUT2 allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient.
    2. Glucose diffuses across the basolateral membrane into the bloodstream.
  7. Glucose is carried away by the bloodstream to various tissues and organs for utilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Involves direct use of ATP for the movement of substances against their concentration gradient and does not apply to glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Passive movement of molecules along their concentration gradient through a membrane protein, applies to the exit of glucose at the basolateral side but not to its uptake at the luminal side.

 

Option D. Any of the above: Not applicable as the specific mechanism for glucose absorption is secondary active transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.
