questions.text: In a 100-m dash, most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphocreatine

 

Phosphocreatine (also called creatine phosphate) is another chemical compound that has a high-energy phosphate bond. The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run.

 

Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aerobic glycolysis: This process occurs in the mitochondria and is used for longer-duration, lower-intensity exercise. It involves the oxidation of glucose to produce ATP, but it is too slow to meet the immediate energy demands of a 100-meter dash.

 

Option C. Oxidation of Fatty acids: This is a slower process involving the breakdown of fatty acids in the mitochondria to produce ATP. It primarily supports prolonged, steady-state activities rather than short bursts of high-intensity exercise.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as phosphocreatine is the primary source of rapid ATP replenishment during short, high-intensity activities like a 100-meter dash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a 100-meter dash, the primary source of energy for rapidly replenishing ATP in skeletal muscles is the phosphagen system, utilizing phosphocreatine for short bursts of maximal muscle power lasting approximately 8 to 10 seconds.

questions.text: Identify the hormone from the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth Hormone

 

The above image shows variations in growth hormone levels through the day.

 

The level is low during the day and is around 5 ng/mL (another reference says <2 ng/mL) increasing in response to specific stimuli like:

 

  1. Exercise.
  2. Physical and emotional stress.
  3. Ingestion of protein.
  4. In hypoglycaemia (Starvation, Fasting)
  5. Spike occurs after 3 hours of meals or exercise.

 

In adults and children in the evening, it shows the highest level.

 

The secretion of GH is episodic and variable; sometimes, the level may reach 40 ng/ml in a healthy subject.

 

The highest values are noted during the deepest sleep level. So, its level is increased during sleep. The GH may increase ten times the normal level during sleep.

 

So, the best time to for growth hormone is 60 to 90 minutes after deep sleep. Or do the exercise for 30 minutes and get the GH sample, which will be at the highest level.

           

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: Incorrect. Cortisol typically peaks in the early morning and lowers throughout the day, not in response to meals or exercise in this marked pattern.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen levels do not show such acute changes in response to daily activities like meals or exercise.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin spikes are typically observed post-meal but would not show the pattern of peaks associated with exercise or sleep as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone levels exhibit significant variability, influenced by factors such as time of day, meals, exercise, and sleep, with the highest levels occurring during deep sleep. This pattern underlines the hormone's critical roles in growth, metabolism, and recovery processes.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DCT

 

 

Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule. The juxtaglomerular complex consists of macula densa cells in the initial portion of the distal tubule and juxtaglomerular cells in the walls of the afferent and efferent arterioles.

 

The macula densa is a specialized group of epithelial cells in the distal tubules that comes in close contact with the afferent and efferent arterioles. The macula densa cells contain Golgi apparatus, which are intracellular secretory organelles directed toward the arterioles, suggesting that these cells may be secreting a substance toward the arterioles.

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is the mechanism that regulates GFR through renal tubule and macula densa. When the glomerular filtrate passes through the terminal portion of thick ascending segment, macula densa acts like a sensor. It detects the concentration of sodium chloride in the tubular fluid and accordingly alters the glomerular blood flow and GFR. Macula densa detects the sodium chloride concentration via Na+K+2Cl– cotransporter (NKCC2).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The proximal convoluted tubule is involved in the reabsorption of water, ions, and nutrients, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option C. Afferent arteriole: Incorrect. The afferent arteriole brings blood into the glomerulus and contains juxtaglomerular cells, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option D. Bowman's capsule: Incorrect. Bowman's capsule surrounds the glomerulus and is involved in the initial filtration of blood to form urine but does not form the macula densa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa, formed by cells of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), is crucial for sensing sodium chloride concentration in the tubular fluid and regulating glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Cellular junctions present in a cardiac muscle are all except? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zonula occludens

 

Zonula occludens is the other name for the tight junction. It is absent in a cardiac muscle.

 

Cardiac muscle fibers are striated bound by sarcolemma with a centrally placed nucleus.

 

Myofibrils are embedded in the sarcoplasm.

 

Sarcomere of the cardiac muscle has all the contractile proteins, namely actin, myosin, troponin and tropomyosin. Cardiac muscle fiber is branched.

 

Intercalated disk - formed by the fusion of the membrane of the cardiac muscle branches.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Fascia adherens - broad intercellular junction both of sarcolemma and intercalated disc of cardiac muscle fibers that anchors actin filaments.

 

Option C. Gap junction - fused membranes adjacent muscle fibers form gap junctions. It is permeable to ions and it facilitates the rapid conduction of action potential from one fiber to another.

 

Option D. Macula adherens - Also called as desmosomes are intercellular junctions specialized for strong adhesion. They prevent the separation of cardiac myocytes during individual fiber contraction by binding to intracellular intermediate filaments (cytoskeleton), which joins cells together.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Zonula occludens are absent in cardiac muscle; instead, this muscle type prominently features fascia adherens, gap junctions, and macula adherens, which are essential for mechanical stability and coordinated contraction.

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, polyanionic

 

Based on the given graph, that A has the highest filterability, followed by B and C, it is likely that A has a smaller size and/or a positive charge, making it easier to pass through the filtration membrane. Similarly, C is likely larger and/or negatively charged, leading to reduced filterability. Therefore, the answer would be: Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

 

Negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for the differential filtration of charged substances. The order of filterability observed in the graph suggests that A is polycationic, B is neutral, and C is polyanionic. This is because polycationic substances would be readily filtered due to their positive charge, while polyanionic substances would be repelled by the negatively charged barrier and exhibit low filterability. Neutral substances would fall somewhere in between, depending on their size and shape. The molecular size exclusion limit you mentioned (between 4-8 nm) is also important for determining which substances are able to be filtered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filterability of substances through the kidney glomerular filtration barrier depends on their charge and size. Polycationic substances (positively charged) filter most readily, neutral substances have intermediate filterability, and polyanionic substances (negatively charged) have the least filterability due to repulsion by the negatively charged barrier.

questions.text: The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

 

Option A. Dehydration: Loss of body fluids leads to increased osmolarity, which stimulates osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus, triggering the sensation of thirst.

 

Option B. Hemorrhage: Significant blood loss decreases blood volume and blood pressure, activating the thirst mechanism to restore fluid balance.

 

Option C. Prandial Drinking: Eating triggers signals that activate thirst neurons via SFO (Subfornical Organ) in the brain, prompting the urge to drink. This anticipatory drinking helps facilitate digestion and prevent future dehydration caused by ingested solutes.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels. During this period, a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus. A new action potential cannot occur in an excitable fiber as long as the membrane is still depolarized from the preceding action potential. This is because shortly after the action potential is initiated, the sodium channels become inactivated, and no amount of excitatory signal applied to these channels at this point will open the inactivation gates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Opening of calcium channels: Incorrect. The opening of calcium channels is not related to the absolute refractory period.

 

Option B. Closure of potassium channels: Incorrect. The closure of potassium channels does not define the absolute refractory period.

 

Option C. Closure of active gates of sodium channel: Incorrect. The closure of active gates does not account for the absolute refractory period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels, preventing the initiation of a new action potential during this period.

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rectal

 

In the given clinical scenario measuring rectal temperature would be preferred over other methods in a case of suspected hypothermia, especially in a soldier posted in Siachen where the ambient temperature can be extremely low. Rectal temperature is considered the most accurate method for measuring core body temperature because it reflects the temperature of the body's core organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral: Incorrect. Oral temperature measurements can be influenced by ambient temperature and recent oral intake, making them less reliable in extreme conditions.

 

Option C. Infrared tympanic thermometer: Incorrect. While it measures the temperature of the eardrum, which can represent core body temperature, it may not be reliable if not inserted adequately or if there is earwax obstruction.

 

Option D. Axillary: Incorrect. Axillary temperature measurements are less accurate and can be significantly influenced by environmental factors, making them unreliable in cold environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate measurement of core body temperature in cases of suspected hypothermia, rectal temperature is the preferred method, especially in extreme environmental conditions like those in Siachen.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptin

 

The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin.

 

Leptin is a peptide hormone released from adipocytes

 

Leptin plays an important role in controlling the adipose tissue and food intake.

 

Actions of leptin:

 

  • Acts on hypothalamus and inhibits the feeding center, resulting in stoppage of food intake
  • Stimulates the metabolic reactions involved in utilization of fat stored in adipose tissue for energy. Thus, the circulating leptin level informs the brain about the energy storage and the necessity to regulate metabolic reactions, food intake and body weight
  • Elevated leptin levels might have a permissive effect on the pubertal process and pubertal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH: Incorrect as GnRH directly stimulates the secretion of LH and FSH, which are critical for puberty but not considered permissive.

 

Option C. Insulin: While it plays a supportive role in general growth and development, it is not specifically permissive for the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. GH: Growth hormone is vital for growth and development during puberty but does not have a direct permissive role in the initiation of puberty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty, indicating to the hypothalamus that sufficient energy reserves are available for the safe progression of reproductive development. This hormone essentially "permits" the initiation of puberty when energy conditions are met.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 only

 

During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

 

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

 

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

 

 

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane generating local end-plate potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, via activating voltage gated Ca2+ channels, leading to the spread of depolarization.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre releases of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • Cross-linkages formed between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

 

Steps in relaxation:

 

 

Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction specially in smooth and cardiac muscle, when there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3, 4: Incorrect. Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria do not play a direct role in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 4: Incorrect. Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important for skeletal muscle contraction, and Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Incorrect. Although Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (statement 3 is correct), Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important and voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During skeletal muscle contraction, Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle contraction.

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Connexons are involved in electrical synapse

 

 

Electrical synapses are characterized by direct open fluid channels that conduct electricity from one cell to the next. Most of these consist of small protein tubular structures called gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next. By way of gap junctions and other similar junctions that action potentials are transmitted from one smooth muscle fiber to the next in visceral smooth muscle and from one cardiac muscle cell to the next in cardiac muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane: Incorrect. This statement describes chemical synapses, not electrical synapses.

 

Option B. Direction of impulse is unidirectional: Incorrect. Electrical synapses can conduct impulses bidirectionally, whereas chemical synapses typically conduct impulses unidirectionally.

 

Option D. Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse: Incorrect. Electrical synapses have a shorter latent period compared to chemical synapses due to the direct transfer of ions through connexons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical synapses involve connexons, which are gap junctions that allow direct ion flow between adjacent cells, facilitating rapid and synchronized electrical communication.

choices.text: Dead space volume

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dead space volume

 

Air in the respiratory passages where gas exchange does not occur, such as the nose, pharynx, and trachea are called dead space.

 

Anatomical dead space can be measured by the single-breath N2 curve (Fowler's method).

 

  • In making this measurement, the subject suddenly takes a deep breath of oxygen.
  • This fills the entire dead space with pure oxygen. Some oxygen also mixes with the alveolar air but does not completely replace this air.
  • Then the person expires through a rapidly recording nitrogen meter, which makes the record
  • Record of the changes in nitrogen concentration in the expired air after a single previous inspiration of pure oxygen. This record can be used to calculate dead space.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): Incorrect. FRC is usually measured using techniques such as body plethysmography or helium dilution, not the single breath nitrogen method.

 

Option C. Tidal volume: Incorrect. Tidal volume is the amount of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breath and is measured directly using spirometry.

 

Option D. Diffusion capacity: Incorrect. Diffusion capacity, often measured by the DLCO (Diffusing Capacity of the Lungs for Carbon Monoxide) test, assesses the ability of gases to diffuse across the alveolar-capillary membrane, not by the single breath nitrogen method.

 

Educational Objective

 

The single breath nitrogen method (Fowler's method) is used to measure the anatomical dead space volume, which is the volume of air in the respiratory passages where no gas exchange occurs. This method provides a precise measurement of dead space by analyzing the nitrogen concentration in expired air following a single breath of pure oxygen.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central inhibition: Incorrect. Central inhibition is not the primary mechanism of action for TENS in pain relief.

 

Option B. Desensitization: Incorrect. Desensitization refers to a reduction in response to a stimulus over time, which is not the primary mechanism for TENS.

 

Option D. Descending inhibition: Incorrect. While descending inhibitory pathways are involved in the modulation of pain, the gate control theory specifically explains the mechanism behind TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large diameter afferent fibers.

choices.text: Burst forming units
Colony forming units
Late erythroblast stage

questions.text: The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burst forming units

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin (EPO) primarily acts on early erythroid progenitor cells, particularly the Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid (BFU-E). The BFU-E is among the earliest erythroid progenitor cells and requires EPO to proliferate and differentiate into more mature forms of red blood cell precursors.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • BFU-E: The Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid is sensitive to erythropoietin and under its influence can proliferate and differentiate, giving rise to Colony Forming Unit-Erythroid (CFU-E).
  • CFU-E: This stage follows BFU-E and leads to the development of more differentiated erythroid cells.
  • Role of EPO: EPO binds to specific receptors on the surface of erythroid progenitor cells, initiating a cascade of intracellular events that promote cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Colony forming units: This is a later stage than BFU-E and is also influenced by EPO but not the earliest.

 

Option C. Late erythroblast stage: EPO's influence diminishes as cells mature to this stage.

 

Option D. Normoblast stage: This is a more mature stage of erythroid development where EPO has minimal effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is most effective at the burst forming unit stage of red blood cell development, where it stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of these early progenitor cells into more mature red blood cells.

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

 

The above shows the compliance diagram of lung

 

Compliance Diagram of the Lungs

 

It is a diagram relating lung volume changes to changes in transpulmonary pressure. 

 

The characteristics of the compliance diagram are determined

 

The surfactant, secreted by type II pneumocytes, reduces surface tension in alveoli.


During inspiration, alveoli expand, decreasing the surfactant concentration, which leads to increased surface tension, requiring more pressure to keep alveoli open.


During expiration, alveoli deflate, increasing surfactant concentration, thus decreasing surface tension, and requiring less pressure.


This asymmetry in surface tension during inspiration and expiration contributes to the difference in the trajectory (hysteresis) of the curve
 

The tissue elastic forces tending to cause collapse of the air-filled lung represent only about one third of the total lung elasticity, whereas the fluid-air surface tension forces in the alveoli represent about two thirds.

 

Thus, a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway due to surface tension at the air-water interface due to surfactant deficit, than to keep an open airway from closing, reflecting abundant surfactant.

 

 

 

Surfactant concentration increases during expiration (smaller alveoli → surfactant molecules closer), lowering surface tension and making expiration easier compared to inspiration. This is the correct cause of hysteresis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration: Incorrect, as this refers to the pressure gradients that drive airflow but does not directly cause the loop shape differences seen in the compliance graph.

 

Option C. Airway resistance can be higher during expiration due to dynamic airway compression, especially in obstructive diseases.

However, the P-V loop is a static curve, plotted during slow, controlled breathing or when airflow has ceased — not during forced maneuvers — so airway resistance has minimal impact on this loop. This might be more relevant to flow-volume loops, not pressure-volume loops

 

Option D. This is true physiologically — inspiration involves active muscle contraction, and expiration is usually passive at rest. But this does not explain the hysteresis in the pressure-volume loop.  The loop reflects lung compliance and surface tension, not the energy used for breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The difference between inspiratory and expiratory pressure-volume loops (hysteresis) is primarily due to dynamic changes in surfactant concentration, which alters surface tension between inspiration and expiration. Understanding this helps explain lung compliance behavior and the role of surfactant in stabilizing alveoli.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior olivary nucleus

 

The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

 

The inferior olivary nucleus is a key part of the cerebellar circuitry and is responsible for providing input to the Purkinje cells via the climbing fibers. These fibers make direct synaptic connections with Purkinje cells and are involved in the modulation of motor learning, control, and coordination. The inferior olivary nucleus receives a wide range of inputs from other areas of the brain, including the spinal cord and sensory systems, and is thought to play an important role in the integration of sensory and motor information during movement.

 

Excitatory and inhibitory fibres –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raphe nucleus: Primarily associated with serotonin production, influencing many brain functions including mood and sleep, but does not directly connect to Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Vestibular nucleus: Sends information to the cerebellum about head position and movement via mossy fibers, not directly to Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Locus coeruleus: Provides widespread noradrenergic projections that influence arousal and attentiveness, not directly targeting Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus directly synapse onto Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, playing a pivotal role in motor control and learning processes.

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides? (AIIMS Nov 2018
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative feedback

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies changes and does not stabilize blood pressure.

 

Option C. Both negative and positive feedback: Incorrect. Baroreceptors primarily provide negative feedback to regulate blood pressure.

 

Option D. Feedforward control: Incorrect. Feedforward control anticipates changes and adjusts accordingly, but baroreceptors respond to changes rather than anticipating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback to help maintain blood pressure within normal limits by triggering responses that counteract increases in blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrin

 

Gastrin does not act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth.

 

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Secretin is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of acidic chyme. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which helps neutralize the acidity of the chyme entering the small intestine.

 

Option C. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of fats and proteins. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete digestive enzymes, including pancreatic amylase, lipase, and proteases, which aid in the digestion of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins.

 

Option D. GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide), also known as gastric inhibitory polypeptide, is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of nutrients, particularly glucose and fat. While its primary role is to stimulate the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells in response to elevated blood glucose levels, it also indirectly influences the pancreas by enhancing the release of pancreatic enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrin does not act on the pancreas. Instead, it stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth, while Secretin, CCK, and GIP have direct or indirect actions on the pancreas.

questions.text: Slow waves are generated by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial cells of Cajal

 

Slow waves appear to be caused by complex interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

Interstitial cells of Cajal form a network with each other and are interposed between the smooth muscle layers, with synaptic-like contacts to smooth muscle cells and undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that periodically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that may generate slow wave activity.

 

The slow waves mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction. The slow waves by themselves do not cause muscle contraction except in the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myenteric neurons: Incorrect. Myenteric neurons are part of the enteric nervous system and play a role in regulating gut motility, but they do not generate slow waves.

 

Option B. Smooth muscle cells: Incorrect. Smooth muscle cells respond to slow waves but do not generate them.

 

Option D. Parasympathetic neurons: Incorrect. Parasympathetic neurons modulate gut activity through the autonomic nervous system but do not generate slow waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract are generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

choices.text: Strength of muscle contraction
Intensity of stimulus
Amplitude of action potential
Duration of stimulus

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensity of stimulus

 

The Weber-Fechner law is a psychophysical law that describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the resulting sensation.

 

According to this law, the perceived magnitude of a sensory stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity. In other words, as the intensity of the stimulus increases, the change needed to produce a noticeable difference in sensation also increases, and this relationship is logarithmic rather than linear.

 

The law was first formulated by the German scientists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner in the mid-19th century and has since been applied to a wide range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, and touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of muscle contraction: This is unrelated to the Weber-Fechner law, which does not concern muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Amplitude of action potential: While action potentials are critical for neural transmission, the Weber-Fechner law specifically relates to the perception of stimulus intensity, not the electrical properties of neurons.

 

Option D. Duration of stimulus: The duration of a stimulus affects perception in different ways but is not the focus of the Weber-Fechner law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Weber-Fechner law illustrates the logarithmic relationship between the actual intensity of a stimulus and the perceived intensity, emphasizing that the human sensory system scales the perception of stimulus magnitude logarithmically rather than linearly.

 

Additional information Other Laws in Physiology:

 

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies states that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important.
  • Law of projection - Regardless of stimulation point for a particular sensory pathway (along its course to cortex), conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of receptor.

Arrange the sequence of evets occurring after p wave in ECG? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

The sequence of events following the P wave in an ECG is: a wave in JVP, first heart sound, T wave (Electrical activity first i.e. repolarization) followed by rapid filling of ventricles (Mechanical activity i.e. relaxation).

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of? How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convergence

 

Convergence refers to the process by which multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, resulting in the integration of information from different sources. In this scenario, the single neuron is receiving inputs from 150 sensory neurons, indicating that there is convergence of input onto the single neuron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Divergence: Divergence occurs when a single neuron sends its axon to synapse with multiple downstream neurons. This process spreads information from one neuron to many.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: This is a regulatory mechanism where a neuron sends a signal to inhibit its own activity indirectly through a network of intermediate neurons. It’s not relevant to the scenario described.

 

Option D. Feedforward excitation: This mechanism involves a neuron sending excitatory signals to downstream neurons to propagate an action potential. It’s not directly related to the scenario described.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Convergence is when multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, integrating inputs from various sources. In the scenario described, where one neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, convergence is the appropriate term.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

In Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there is an increase in both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC). These changes occur due to air trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, which are characteristic of COPD.

 

  • FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. This increases in COPD due to air trapping.
  • TLC (Total Lung Capacity): The maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. It may be increased or remain normal in COPD due to hyperinflation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In COPD, both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC) increase due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation.

questions.text: Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Temperature

 

Feed forward control system is employed during regulation of temperature.

 

This is the control system of our body that anticipates and makes corrective changes without any stimulus. Such a system is called Feed forward or Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

 

For instance, some movements of the body occur so rapidly that there is not enough time for nerve signals to travel from the peripheral parts of the body all the way to the brain and then back to the periphery again to control the movement. Therefore, the brain uses a principle called feed-forward control to cause required muscle contractions wherein sensory nerve signals from the moving parts inform the brain whether the movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscles the next time the movement is required. Then, if still further correction is needed, this will be done again for subsequent movements. This is called adaptive control.

 

Examples include:

 

  • Thermoregulation by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature changes the body's core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Increase in gastric acid secretion on thinking about food
  • Thinking about exercise leading to increase heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Motor coordination by cerebellum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood volume: Incorrect. The regulation of blood volume is primarily a feedback mechanism based on circulating blood volume and blood pressure.

 

Option B. pH: Incorrect. pH regulation in the body involves feedback mechanisms that monitor and adjust to changes in hydrogen ion concentration.

 

Option D. Blood pressure: Incorrect. While there are anticipatory aspects in blood pressure regulation during activities like exercise, it's primarily governed by feedback mechanisms responding to changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The feed forward control system is a preemptive regulatory mechanism employed notably in temperature regulation, allowing the body to anticipate environmental changes and adjust physiological responses in advance to maintain homeostasis.

questions.text:
Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GFM for a patient with the data given below? (AIIMS May 2018)

 

Glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient = 6

Glomerular hydrostatic pressure =45

Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure =20

Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure =10

Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure =0
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 15 mmHg

 

Four primary forces that determine whether fluid will move out of the blood into the interstitial fluid or in the opposite direction. These forces are:

 

  1. The capillary pressure (Pc), which tends to force fluid outward through the capillary membrane.
  2. The interstitial fluid pressure (Pif), which tends to force fluid inward through the capillary membrane when Pif is positive but outward when Pif is negative.
  3. The capillary plasma colloid osmotic pressure (Pp), which tends to cause osmosis of fluid inward through the capillary membrane.
  4. The interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure (Cif), which tends to cause osmosis of fluid outward through the capillary membrane.

 

If the sum of these forces, the net filtration pressure, is positive, there will be a net fluid filtration across the capillaries. If the sum of the Starling forces is negative, there will be a net fluid absorption from the interstitial spaces into the capillaries.

 

The net filtration pressure (NFP) is calculated as:

 

NFP = Pc - Pif - Pp + Cif


Where Pc – Capillary pressure, Pif is Interstitial fluid pressure, Pp is plasma colloid osmotic pressure, Cif is interstitial colloid osmotic pressure

 

Therefore, Net filtration pressure = 45 – 10 – 20 + 0 = 15mmHg

 

Educational Objective:

 

The net filtration pressure (NFP) in the glomerulus, essential for kidney filtration, is calculated based on the differences between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures inside and outside the glomerular capillaries. In this scenario, an NFP of 15 mmHg favors the formation of urine by pushing fluid out of blood vessels into the Bowman's capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

 

The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

The calculation of creatinine clearance involves the following parameters:

 

Option A. Urine creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the urine, typically measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option B. Serum creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the blood, also measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option C. 24-hour urine output: This is the total volume of urine produced in 24 hours, measured in milliliters (mL).

questions.text: If the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimum volume

 

If lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be minimum volume. This is due to the inherent elastic properties of the lung tissue, which tend to make the lungs contract inward when not counteracted by the outward elastic recoil of the chest wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zero: Incorrect. The lung cannot have zero volume due to the presence of air in the alveoli and residual airways even at its minimal state.

 

Option C. Functional residual capacity: Incorrect. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration, which includes the balance between the inward recoil of the lungs and the outward recoil of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. The minimum volume after elastic recoil without the chest wall support would be less than the residual volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the lung undergoes elastic recoil without the chest wall, it would collapse to its minimum volume due to the lung's inherent elastic properties.

questions.text: In the motor homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Precision of movements

 

Precision of movements has maximum representation in the motor homunculus.

 

In the sensory homunculus, the relative sizes of the cortical areas is proportional to the use of the part, the number of specialized sensory receptors and precision required by respective peripheral area of the body.

 

Some body parts like lips are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex followed by the face and thumb while the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low control and skilled movements: Incorrect, as areas requiring low control do not have extensive cortical representation.

 

Option B. More muscle fibres are present: Incorrect, as the size of representation in the motor homunculus is not based on the number of muscle fibers, but rather on the precision and complexity of movements.

 

Option D. Intensity of perception: Incorrect, as intensity of perception is related to sensory input and the sensory homunculus, not the motor homunculus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The motor homunculus has maximum representation for body parts requiring precision of movements, reflecting the complexity and intricacy needed for fine motor control.

questions.text:
Which of the following organelles is absent in the area of the cardiac muscle marked:  
(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosome

 

Lysosomes are not typically concentrated in the marked perinuclear area of cardiac muscle cells. Instead, lysosomes are distributed throughout the cytoplasm of the cell. This means that they are present in the cell but do not show a significant concentration or structure in the indicated area of cardiac muscle fibers.

 

In cardiac muscle cells, mitochondria are abundant due to the high-energy demand for contraction, and endoplasmic reticulum (sarcoplasmic reticulum) and Golgi bodies are usually present in the perinuclear area for synthesis and modification of proteins and other important molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are highly abundant in cardiac muscle cells, particularly near areas that need significant energy. The heart has a high demand for ATP due to its continuous contractions, and mitochondria are essential for this energy supply.

 

Option C. Golgi bodies: Golgi bodies are present in cardiac muscle cells, often localized around the perinuclear area. They are important for modifying, packaging, and sorting proteins, which are needed in various cellular functions, including those in muscle contraction and maintenance.

 

Option D. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER): The endoplasmic reticulum (or sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells) is crucial for calcium storage and release, which is essential for muscle contraction. It is indeed present in cardiac muscle cells and has a significant role in the regulation of contraction and relaxation cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are widely distributed throughout the cytoplasm of cells,

 

  1. Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles 
  2. The enzymes within lysosomes are responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials, such as proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and even organelles.
  3. Lysosomes play a crucial role in cellular homeostasis by recycling and eliminating unwanted or damaged cellular components through a process known as autophagy.
  4. The acidic environment within lysosomes (pH around 4.5-5) is necessary for the optimal activity of the digestive enzymes.

 

Lysosomal storage disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher's disease, occur when there is a malfunction or deficiency of enzymes within lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of undigested materials and subsequent cellular dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of feed forward control mechanism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exercise resulting in increased heart rate

 

Feedforward mechanism is the control system of our body that anticipates and makes corrective changes without any stimulus. Also called as Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

 

For instance, some movements of the body occur so rapidly that there is not enough time for nerve signals to travel from the peripheral parts of the body all the way to the brain and then back to the periphery again to control the movement.

The cerebellum uses feed-forward to predict the sensory consequences of a movement before it is executed. This allows for proactive adjustments and smooth, coordinated movements, especially in learned or repetitive movements. The cerebellum helps in estimating the body's future state, compensating for delays in sensory feedback, calculating prediction errors, and adjusting motor commands accordingly

 

Examples include

 

  • Thermoregulation by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature changes the body's core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Increase in gastric acid secretion on thinking about food
  • THINKING about exercise leading to increase heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Cerebellar motor coordination before movement execution 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Temperature Regulation: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where the hypothalamus anticipates and adjusts for temperature changes.

 

Option B. Cephalic phase of gastric secretion: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where thinking about food triggers gastric secretions in anticipation of eating.

 

Option C. Cerebellar action in motor coordination: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where the cerebellum coordinates movements by predicting the required muscle contractions.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: What is the usual position of the Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supranuclear

 

Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. Serous acinar cells are generally found in pancreas and the submandibular salivary glands.

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi complex is involved in the modification and packaging of secretory proteins into vesicles that can be transported to the apical surface of the cell for release into the ducts or glands. The supranuclear location of the Golgi complex in these cells allows for efficient transport of these vesicles to the apical surface for secretion.

 

In contrast, other organelles such as the nucleus, mitochondria, and rough endoplasmic reticulum are typically located in the basal or perinuclear regions of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal: Incorrect, as the basal region is typically where the nucleus and other organelles like mitochondria are located.

 

Option C. Adjacent to nucleus: Incorrect, while the Golgi apparatus is near the nucleus, it is specifically located above the nucleus in the supranuclear position in serous acinar cells.

 

Option D. Apical: Incorrect, as the Golgi apparatus itself is not located in the apical region, though it directs secretory vesicles to this area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi apparatus is typically located in the supranuclear region, facilitating the modification and transport of secretory proteins for efficient secretion into the glandular ducts.

choices.text: Degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in primordial germ cells of males

questions.text: Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Hormone degradation regulates local concentrations is seen in all of the above.

 

  • In renal tubular cells, glucocorticoids are inactivated by 11ß-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.
  • Breakdown of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 during development prevents meiosis in the male primordial germ cells.
  • The thyroid hormone 5’ deiodinases convert T4 to T3 and can inactivate T3 (Reverse T3) via 5 deiodinases.

 

Hormones are “cleared” from the plasma in several ways, including:

 

  1. Metabolic destruction by the tissues
  2. Binding with the tissues
  3. Excretion by the liver into the bile
  4. Excretion by the kidneys into the urine

 

Hormones are sometimes degraded at their target cells by enzymatic processes that cause endocytosis of the cell membrane hormone-receptor complex; the hormone is then metabolized in the cell, and the receptors are usually recycled back to the cell membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone degradation is a vital regulatory mechanism observed in various processes, including the inactivation of glucocorticoids by 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, the conversion and inactivation of thyroid hormones by 5 deiodinases, and the degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in male primordial germ cells.
